Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Ohio River Analysis Meetings 2014-2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a three-year run of the Ohio River Analysis Meeting that is hosted by (in alternate years) the University of Kentucky and the University of Cincinnati; the first conference in this sequence will run in March of 2014. In 2015 the conference will run at the University of Cincinnati and in 2016 it returns to the University of Kentucky.


This annual conference is centered on the recent developments in the field of Analysis, and in particular in the subfields of partial differential equations and mathematical physics. Through plenary lectures the conference will provide an opportunity for regional mathematicians, postdocs, and graduate students to attend state-of-the-art talks and to confer with leading researchers in the field of Analysis. Through contributed talks the meeting will provide a venue for young mathematicians to present their results to a distinguished audience. An overarching goal is to foster cooperation and collaboration amongst analysis researchers in the Ohio Valley region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Ohio River Analysis Meeting (ORAM) is a collaborative project between analysts at the University of Kentucky (UK) and the University of Cincinnati (UC) started in 2011. The meetings are held in the spring of each academic year and the site alternates between UK and UC each year. The meetings bring together regional researchers from the Ohio Valley and beyond in analysis and partial differential equations. Faculty, post-docs, and students, both graduate and advanced undergraduate, attend state-of-the art invited talks and discuss recent developments in the field. The meetings are managed by 6 mathematicians: 3 at UK and 3 at UC.The meetings also serve to show case the work of young researchers through contributed talks. Each meeting features five invited distinguished speakers and approximately thirty contributed talks. Funds from this award supported participants and principal lecturers at ORAM 4 and ORAM 6 hosted by the University of Kentucky in March 2014 and March 2016, respectively. Funds from the grant also supported researchers from the University of Kentucky so they could attend ORAM 5 in 2015 at the University of Cincinnati. NSF supported other participants in ORAM 5 through a grant to the University of Cincinnati. Overall, 43 young researchers, out of 140 participants, and five of the ten principal lecturers, were supported by the grant for ORAM 4 and ORAM 6. Approximately 20% of those supported were women. Two of the five principal lecturers at each meeting were women. The young people supported by the grant gave contributed talks on their research. ORAM has developed into a forum where young mathematicians specializing in analysis and partial differential equations go to present their work before an interested and experienced audience. When ORAM is hosted at UK, it receives financial support from the Mathematics Department, the College of Arts and Sciences, and the Office of the Vice President for Research. ORAM is advertised through our ORAM email list and the AMS electronic calendar. The meetings are also offered in cooperation with the Association for Women in Mathematics and listed on their electronic calendar. The programs of all ORAMs are archived and available at:  http://homepages.uc.edu/~goldbeml/ORAM/
